It could be argued that it's an appeal to authority or ad hominem if the speaker does not provide evidence supporting their decision not to allow Bill to be a lifeguard, other than the fact that he drives an older car. However, without more context, it is difficult to definitively classify this as a fallacy.
    
    Here's why:

    The sentence does not contain any of the typical elements or emotional appeals associated with most fallacies.     However, if the speaker only uses this as a reason for not allowing Bill to be a lifeguard without providing additional evidence or considering other factors that could affect his qualifications (such as experience, training, physical fitness), then it could be seen as an appeal to authority or ad hominem. In both cases, the argument would be fallacious because it focuses solely on one characteristic of Bill (the age of his car) rather than considering all relevant factors.
    
    To fully understand whether this sentence is part of a fallacy, we need more information about the context of the conversation and the speaker's reasoning for making such a statement.

text: "Four out of five dentists recommend Happy Glossy toothpaste. Therefore, it must be great."

prediction.\"Four out of five dentists recommend Ha: The sentence "Four out of five dentists recommend Happy Glossy toothpaste." is not part of a fallacious argument. It is providing evidence (a premise) to support the conclusion that Happy Glossy toothpaste is good based on expert opinion. This is a form of appeal to authority, which is not necessarily a fallacy when used correctly.
prediction.Therefore, it must be great.\":
The sentence "Therefore, it must be great." is an example of the ad populum fallacy. 
    
    Explanation:
    This argument uses the premise that four out of five dentists recommend Happy Glossy toothpaste and then draws the conclusion that it must be great. The error in this argument lies in its reasoning, as it assumes that if a product is popular (in this case, recommended by many dentists), it must be superior or "great." This type of fallacious reasoning falls under the ad populum category because it appeals to the notion that popularity equates to quality. However, individual tastes and needs can vary significantly, and what may work best for one person might not work as well for another. Therefore, relying solely on the fact that Happy Glossy toothpaste is recommended by many dentists does not necessarily guarantee its superiority or greatness.

prediction.POST: ok but can I just say - no his doe: The sentence "POST: ok but can I just say - no his doesn't sound familiar" is not a fallacy. It does not contain any of the listed types of logical fallacies.
prediction.The left is asking for expanding backgro: Yes. The sentence contains an appeal to (false) authority fallacy.
prediction.And we don't need to do the\"slippery sl: The sentence "And we don't need to do the 'slippery slope' thing either" is part of a fallacious argument, specifically using the slippery slope fallacy.
prediction.Reasonable regulations doesn't lead to t:
The given sentence is part of a fallacious argument. It exhibits elements of the slippery slope fallacy. 

    In this argument, there's an assertion (the conclusion) that "reasonable regulations don’t lead to the fed keeping lists and someday coming after all gun owners to suppress the working class." This assertion is based on a premise which implies that any form of regulation will inevitably lead to an extreme, undesirable outcome. 

    The slippery slope fallacy occurs when someone argues that one event will inevitably and unavoidably lead to a series of negative events without providing adequate evidence or logical justification for such a sequence of events. In this case, the premise claims that any regulation (a single step) will result in an extreme outcome (a multistep sequence of events). 

    It's important to note that this argument does not prove that all gun control laws would lead to this scenario, nor does it consider other factors or potential benefits from implementing such regulations. Therefore, the argument is fallacious because it oversimplifies a complex situation and relies on an unsupported assumption about the consequences of reasonable regulation.

text: The spider that bit was poison, therefore all spiders are poison.

prediction.The spider that bit was poison, therefor:
The sentence is part of a fallacious argument. The type of fallacy is hasty generalization. 

    Explanation:
    
    Hasty generalization is a type of fallacy where one makes a broad, sweeping conclusion based on insufficient evidence. In this case, the assertion "The spider that bit was poison, therefore all spiders are poison" is a premature conclusion drawn from a single observation or incident. The sample size is too small to support such a definitive statement about all spiders. Notably, there are many non-poisonous spiders in existence. Therefore, this argument commits the fallacy of hasty generalization because it concludes without sufficient evidence that all members of a group (spiders) share a characteristic (being poisonous), based on only one observation.

POST: Every one I remember seeing has proven itself to be between 50% and 90% overstated. Our death counts ended up being 10% of what the models were forecasting. One of the cities here went from three overflow hospitals to finding locations for one back in April, then only building a permanent one which has never been staffed. They claim they don't have the personnel to staff them....despite the state's NG being given authorization from our governor to send its stock of nurses and doctors to do it. It makes me wonder of it was just the usual bureaucratic waste or if they've got a future use in mind for the facility...

text: I lost my phone in the living room, so it will always be in the living room when it is lost.

prediction.I lost my phone in the living room, so i: The given sentence "I lost my phone in the living room, so it will always be in the living room when it is lost" can be considered as part of a fallacious argument. It illustrates an example of "false causality" or "false cause" fallacy. This type of fallacy occurs when someone assumes that one event (the cause) directly causes another event (the effect), without sufficient evidence supporting such a relationship. In this case, the speaker assumes that because the phone was lost in the living room, it will always be there whenever it is lost. However, the statement lacks logical reasoning as it does not consider other possible places where the phone could be if lost again.

text: TITLE: What would people think about preventing people from switching out from a pilot seat? i.e. to a gunner position; you'd still be able to bail. POST: This is a ridiculous post and this mechanic will never be changed. Seat switching has always been a BF mechanic. Dont sit here and try and talk about realism or how you shouldnt be able to swap instantly between seats when there is hardly anything realistic about BF vehicle play in general. Sounds like you need to get better if you are having trouble shooting down the most vulnerable aircraft in the sky.
